newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Sept 12.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Sept 12.

text.p: Gillette Co is near an agreement to acquire Duracell International Inc in a stock deal worth over $7 billion, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.
* The Federal Trade Commission plans to announce Thursday it approved a settlement allowing Time Warner Inc and Turner Broadcasting System Inc to complete their merger.
* Rockwell International Corp and U.S. Robotics Corp are each developing equipment that speeds computer communication over telephone lines.
* The U.S. Food and Drug Administration said some men using a prostate drug made by Merck & Co developed a condition associated with breast cancer.
* Prudential Insurance Co of America plans to sell nearly all of its remaining real-estate holdings, valued at $5.6 billion, over three years.
* Xerox Corp and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co called off the planned $2.3 billion sale of Xerox's Talegen insurance unit to KKR.
* Motorola said weak chip sales and competition in cellular phone sales will hurt third-quarter earnings.
* The Federal Reserve said labor markets tightened and wages rose modestly, but inflation was still in check.
* Federal regulators said bad credit-card debt reached its highest level since 1992, causing banks to write off 36-percent more loans in the latest quarter.
* General Motors Corp offered to guarantee lifetime employment to current United Auto Workers union members in exchange for permission to cut workforces after those members retire.
* Crude oil prices hit five-year highs amid escalating tensions between the United States and Iraq.
* Mutual funds received about $19 billion in stock mutual funds in August, a sharp rebound from July's $5.8 billion.
* MCI Communications Corp projected good growth in its data and network-consulting business.
* Crop prices fell after the government raised it monthly wheat and corn harvest estimates.
* H.J. Heinz Co got a saucy bounce in its stock this week when an announcement that it planned to shed some non-core assets produced headlines heralding a major restructuring. - Heard on the Street
* Bond prices ended little changed after initially dropping on concerns about impending economic data and a jump in oil prices. - Credit Markets
